baseline_groups.claim_summary: In-kind food transfers increase total per-capita household expenditure: the DD interaction term ik_fu is positive and marginally significant (coef=51.80, SE=28.04, p=0.065) in the baseline specification with village-level controls (Diconsa store indicator + month-of-interview FEs) and clustering at the village level.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3, Column 1. Coefficient 51.80 (SE 28.04, p=0.065). N=10828, R2=0.070. This is the paper's primary result for the in-kind treatment arm. The baseline specification includes treatment group indicators (ik, cash), a follow-up period dummy (fu), the DD interactions (ik_fu, cash_fu), and village-level controls (diconsa + month FEs). SEs clustered at the village level (id_loc). Groups 2 and 3 (in-kind with and without nutrition education) are pooled into a single 'in-kind' treatment arm.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Cash transfers also increase total per-capita household expenditure, with a magnitude similar to in-kind transfers, though with less precision: the DD interaction term cash_fu is positive but insignificant (coef=40.44, SE=32.29, p=0.211).
baseline_groups.notes: Same regression as G1 (Table 3, Column 1), but the coefficient of interest is the cash treatment DD interaction (cash_fu). Coefficient 40.44 (SE 32.29, p=0.211). The paper cannot reject equality between ik_fu and cash_fu, establishing that total expenditure effects are similar across transfer modalities.

global_notes: Paper is 'Testing Paternalism: Cash versus In-Kind Transfers' by Cunha (AEJ: Applied Economics). The specification search focuses on the DD estimates from a village-level cluster-RCT in Mexico's PAL program. 208 rural villages were randomized to control, in-kind food transfers, in-kind + nutrition education, or cash + nutrition education. Groups 2 and 3 are pooled as a single 'in-kind' arm in the main analysis. There are 77 total specifications: 69 tracking the in-kind treatment (ik_fu) and 8 tracking the cash treatment (cash_fu). The primary coefficient of interest is ik_fu on pc_exp_total. The baseline specification shows p=0.065, but adding household-level controls brings this to p=0.026 (controls/full_baseline). Key mechanism results show the effect is driven by in-kind basket goods (outcome/pc_exp_inkind: coef=44.32, p<0.001) with negligible effects on non-in-kind food (outcome/pc_exp_n_inkind: coef=-2.81, p=0.856), supporting the 'extra-marginal' consumption interpretation. Outcome decomposition specs (food, nonfood, inkind, non-inkind) are classified as core because they directly test the paper's main claim about the composition of the consumption response. Disaggregated item-level specs (individual food items, nonfood subcategories) are classified as non-core. Placebo tests, heterogeneity splits, and cash treatment outcome decompositions are also non-core. Three placebo specs use the baseline cross-sectional difference (treatment variable 'ik' without interaction) and thus have a different treatment variable structure; they are classified as non-core placebos.
